msContents.summary: It is a copy of the grammar of the Common Tamil composed by the Italian Jesuit Giuseppe Costantino Beschi (1680-1747) in 1728 written in Latin.

p.p: Industrial paper with watermark also found in other manuscripts (i.e. Indien 189, Indien 192, and Indien 617, 634 – see Colas and Colas-Chauhan (1995: 51). It is represented by the letter T surmounted by a crown and placed on a base, itself surmounting a cartouche which contains a J followed by a fleur-de-lis and the name CUSSON (cf. nos. 3292 and 3293, pl. 424 and no. 694, pl 109 in Heawood 1969 [1950]).

extent.measure: 89 written pages + 1 blank page + 1 front guard leaf (U1 + U1a)

supportDesc.foliation: Original foliation on the upper side (right and left) of each page.

collation.desc: cover board: register number = unreadable. the front cover. on cover board. Shelfmark on recto.
89 pages = Tamil grammar written in Latin.
1 folio = Title page. Shelfmark written in black pencil: "Tamoul n° 190"

supportDesc.condition: Very good state of preservation, in spite of bore holes caused by insects.

layout.p: The layout of the page is organized into two rectangules drawn in grey prencil within which the text is organised into two columns.
Upper, bottom, right, and left margins: 100mm.

desc.p: It seems Jean Calmette's hand (1692–1739 or 40) (cf. fond Brotier 89, ff. 21a, 25a, 51a) – who had copied some of the manuscript that were sent from India and entered the Royal library – see his letter from Ballabaram, August, 1731 in fond Brotier 89, fol. 37a, 37b [non vidi, cited in Colas and Colas-Chauhan 1995: 11).

The vowel lenght of e/ois marked with a diacritic consisting in a stroke placed above the V. The same stroke is also used above C to mark that it should be read as accompained by the vowel a or a long vowel.
The puḷḷi appears as a small circle above consonants in intermediate position.
The symbols for ra and long a is not differentiated.

decoNote.desc: Used to mark the beginning of a new paragraph.

desc.p: The stamp (size 200 mm) is found on the title page and at f. 89v: 3 fleur-de-lys in an oval emblem surmounted by a crown. Inscription Royal Library. Period: Restoration, July 1830 - January 1831 (Josserand and Bruno 1960: 282, n. 20).

encodingDesc.p: Transliteration conventions ― Conservative. Hence, puḷḷi, ō, and ē are used only if they are found in the manuscript. ― Abbreviations ― cf. = compare, f = folio, ff. = folios, r = recto, U/u = unit (codicological and/or textual), v = verso.
